title: XSS in the "Poll" Feature on Twitter.com

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information: I have found an XSS on the "Poll" feature on Twitter.com. Payload Example: `` Screenshot: I have attached a screenshot in this submission in order to demonstrate the issue. Best, Mazin
vulnerability_information_html:
I have found an XSS on the "Poll" feature on Twitter.com.

Payload Example:
<img src=x onerror=alert(1)>

Screenshot: I have attached a screenshot in this submission in order to demonstrate the issue.

Best,
Mazin

activities.message: The issue is currently un-exploitable due to CSP.
activities.markdown_message: The issue is currently un-exploitable due to CSP.

activities.message:
Hello, thank you for your report.

By disabling content security policy I was able to get the payload to execute however in my testing it was not possible to create a poll with the XSS payload, but only to preview the creation of it. As such, it appears as though this attack only allows a victim to attack themselves. Can you think of a way an attacker might be able to use this vulnerability in order to carry out an attack against a victim other than themselves?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello, thank you for your report.

By disabling content security policy I was able to get the payload to execute however in my testing it was not possible to create a poll with the XSS payload, but only to preview the creation of it. activities.message:
Hi Andrew,

I have retested the issue, so it looks that Twitter is doing some server-side validations to the user-input. It rejects the request if it contains a malicious input, such as the above payload, and it creates a "card" in the showed in the response, but doesn't show it in the feed if it contains a non-malicuious payload that contains `<` or `>`, such as `<x>`.  

For the CSP part, it can't not be bypassed, unless I have either a valid CSP bypass against a browser, then  I would be able to execute malicious JS freely. Or, if I have write access or XSS in the following domains:
https://connect.facebook.net
https://cm.g.doubleclick.net https://ssl.google-analytics.com
https://graph.facebook.com
https://twitter.com
https://*.userzoom.com
https://*.twimg.com
https://api.twitter.com
https://analytics.twitter.com
https://ton.twitter.com
https://syndication.twitter.com
https://www.google.com
https://platform.twitter.com
https://www.google-analytics.com

If I don't have one of this options, then bypassing CSP would not be done.

Thanks,
Mazin
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Andrew,

I have retested the issue, so it looks that Twitter is doing some server-side validations to the user-input. It rejects the request if it contains a malicious input, such as the above payload, and it creates a "card" in the showed in the response, but doesn't show it in the feed if it contains a non-malicuious payload that contains < or >, such as <x>.

For the CSP part, it can't not be bypassed, unless I have either a valid CSP bypass against a browser, then I would be able to execute malicious JS freely. Or, if I have write access or XSS in the following domains:
https://connect.facebook.net
https://cm.g.doubleclick.net https://ssl.google-analytics.com
https://graph.facebook.com
https://twitter.com

https://.twimg.com

https://ton.twitter.com
https://syndication.twitter.com
https://www.google.com
https://platform.twitter.com
https://www.google-analytics.com

If I don't have one of this options, then bypassing CSP would not be done.

Thanks,
Mazin

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message:
Thank you for bringing this issue to our attention. Unfortunately, this report does not fall in scope for a monetary reward at this time. However, you will still be listed in our Hall of Fame. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.

Please let us know if you find a way to use this to attack another user, for example by pre-populating the fields through the querystring and we may re-evaluate this decision.

activities.message:
Hi Andrew,

Thanks for your comments, I totally agree withe the panel's evaluation, as this issue is considered as a self-XSS, and it's even harder to exploit due to CSP.

I would be thinking about ways to exploit this particular issue, and I will let you know if I find an idea.

Best,
Mazin

activities.message:
Hello Andrew,

I'm following up regarding this issue, I have tested it today and it appears to be still unpatched.

Also, it looks that I haven't mentioned that CSP is not well-supported on Internet Explorer 11 and below. So by testing the issue on Internet Explorer 11, I have been able to execute JS on my testing environment. I have attached a screenshot as a PoC of executing alert() function on IE 11.

Best Regards,
Mazin
activities.markdown_message:
Hello Andrew,

I'm following up regarding this issue, I have tested it today and it appears to be still unpatched.

Also, it looks that I haven't mentioned that CSP is not well-supported on Internet Explorer 11 and below. So by testing the issue on Internet Explorer 11, I have been able to execute JS on my testing environment. I have attached a screenshot as a PoC of executing alert() function on IE 11.

Best Regards,
Mazin

activities.message:
Hi Mazin,

We are still working on this issue and will let you know when it is resolved. We're aware of the limitations in Internet Explorer but don't consider this to present a significant risk. Have you been able to find a way an attacker might be able to use this vulnerability in order to carry out an attack against a victim other than themselves?

Thank you for your patience!

activities.message:
Hi Andrew,

Thanks for your response.
I have not been able to find a way to make the exploitation of this issue to be done without user-interaction.

Best regards,
Mazin

activities.message:
Hi,
I wonder why this issue is taking this large time to be patched. It has been 4 months since I initially reported it.
Thanks,
Mazin

activities.message:
Hi Mazin,

The impact of this issue is still very low and doesn't present a significant amount of risk, though we have it on our backlog of items to address. We will let you know when it is resolved.

Thank you for your patience!
